Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor's task must be completed before upper management’s evaluation tomorrow.
Story: My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” It’s Sunday evening, our sacred time to catch up, laugh, and reassure them I’m doing okay in the city. I know how much they look forward to these calls, especially since I moved out. But my laptop screen glares at me, the unfinished project from my mentor staring back. She assigned it last minute, emphasizing its importance—upper management will review it tomorrow. I can almost hear her voice, “This is your chance to shine. Don’t let me down.” My parents expect warmth and presence; my mentor expects focus and results. My heart pounds as I glance between my phone and the blinking cursor. I want to be a good child, to hear about Dad’s garden and Mom’s new recipe. But I also want to prove myself as a dedicated mentee. The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I feel torn, wishing I could split myself in two.
